title: Capstone Project Launch — My Year in History
description: Students choose their favorite civilization or historical period from the year's studies and begin planning an illustrated research report. This capstone project synthesizes research skills, expository writing, and artistic expression into a single culminating work.
instructions:
1. Review the year's history journey together: 'We have traveled from the beginning of the universe through ancient civilizations, the Middle Ages, the Renaissance, revolutions, world wars, and civil rights. What an incredible journey!'
2. List all major periods and civilizations studied on a large timeline or board.
3. Ask: 'Which civilization or time period fascinated you the most? Which one do you want to become an expert on?'
4. Once the child selects their topic, help them brainstorm what they already know and what they want to learn more about.
5. Create a project planning sheet: title, 3-5 subtopics they want to cover, materials they will need, and a timeline for completion (across weeks 33-34).
6. Begin gathering reference materials — books, notes from earlier lessons, maps, and images.
7. 'This is YOUR big project. You are the author, the illustrator, and the researcher. Let us make it magnificent!'
materials_needed: Large poster board or report folder
Previous history lesson notes and work

slides.heading: My Year in History
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover of a special book you're going to create! It’s called "My Year in History" and it's all about your big project where you get to be a super historian and researcher. We're going to use everything we learned this year to make something really awesome.

slides.setup_instructions: Create a timeline display of the year's history topics for reference. Prepare a simple project planning template with sections for topic, subtopics, materials needed, and schedule.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these cool supplies! We have a big poster board or a folder to put our project in, lined paper for writing, and a special planning sheet to help us organize. We'll also use colorful pencils and markers to make it look amazing, plus books and our old notes for research. And these little index cards are perfect for jotting down interesting facts we discover!

slides.text: Review the year's journey: 'This year we traveled through time — from the Big Bang and Timeline of Life, through Mesopotamia, Egypt, India, China, Greece, and Rome, into the Middle Ages, Renaissance, Scientific Revolution, all the way to modern times. What an extraordinary adventure!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, remember all the amazing places and times we visited this year? We went from the very beginning of time, through ancient Egypt and Rome, all the way to knights and kings, and even big changes in the world. This slide is just reminding us of our incredible journey through history!

slides.text: Ask the child to reflect: 'Close your eyes and think about all these periods. Which one made you the most excited? Which people or events do you most want to tell others about? THAT is your capstone topic.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, close your eyes for a second and think about all those adventures. Which time period or civilization made you say "Wow!" the most? Maybe it was the pharaohs of Egypt, or the brave knights of the Middle Ages? Pick the one that really sparks your curiosity, because that’s what this project is all about!

slides.text: Help plan the project: 'Every great researcher starts with a plan. Let us write down your topic, then list 3 to 5 things you want your report to cover. For example, if you chose Ancient Egypt, you might cover daily life, the pyramids, hieroglyphics, the Nile, and pharaohs.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Every amazing project needs a good plan, right? This step is like drawing a treasure map for your report. We’ll write down your chosen topic, then pick 3 to 5 smaller things you want to learn and share about it, like what people ate or what their homes looked like. This helps us know exactly what to research!

slides.text: Begin note-taking: 'Use index cards to write one fact per card. This way we can organize your facts into sections later. Write the source on the back of each card.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the detective work begins! We’re going to use these index cards to write down one cool fact on each card. It's like collecting puzzle pieces for your project. Writing the source on the back helps us remember where we found that awesome piece of information.

slides.prompt: Choose your favorite civilization or historical period. Create your project plan with a title, 3-5 subtopics, and begin taking notes on index cards. Gather at least 10 facts from your reference materials.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it’s time to dive in! Your mission is to pick your absolute favorite history topic, fill out your planning sheet with a title and those 3-5 subtopics we talked about, and start collecting facts on your index cards. Try to find at least 10 interesting facts from our books and notes – you can do it!

slides.text: Review the project plan together: 'You have a wonderful topic and a solid plan. Over the next two weeks, you will research, write, illustrate, and present this to your family. This is the work of a real historian!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child select a topic, articulate why it interests them, identify subtopics for research, and begin organized note-taking?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at what you’ve accomplished! You picked a fantastic topic and made a great plan for your project. You’ve already started gathering important information like a true historian. Now, over the next couple of weeks, you'll get to write, draw, and share your amazing discoveries!

parent_notes: This capstone project is the culmination of the entire year's history curriculum and embodies Montessori's cosmic education philosophy — the child is connecting themselves to the grand narrative of human civilization. The choice of topic reveals what resonated most deeply with your child's imagination. Honor their choice completely, even if it surprises you. A child who chooses the Industrial Revolution over Ancient Egypt is following their inner teacher. The project planning phase is as important as the writing — it teaches executive function skills (breaking a large task into manageable parts, creating timelines, gathering resources) that will serve them throughout their education. Resist the urge to over-direct; offer support and resources but let the child own the project. This report will span weeks 33-34, with presentation in week 35.

title: Personal Finance — Introduction to Budgeting
description: Students learn the fundamentals of budgeting by creating a simple budget for a pretend family outing. They apply addition, subtraction, and decision-making to allocate a fixed amount of money across categories, discovering that math is essential for real-world financial decisions.
instructions:
1. 'Today we are going to use all our math skills for something very real — managing money! Every family has to decide how to spend their money wisely.'
2. Present the scenario: 'Your family has $100 to spend on a fun day out. You need to plan the whole day within this budget.'
3. Provide a price list for various activities and items: museum entry ($12/person), movie tickets ($10/person), lunch at a restaurant ($8/person), ice cream ($4/person), park (free), library (free), bus fare ($2/person), souvenirs ($5-$15), etc.
4. Assume a family of 4 people.
5. Child creates a budget by listing chosen activities and calculating total costs using multiplication and addition.
6. 'Did you stay within the $100? If not, what can you adjust? This is what budgeting is all about — making choices.'
7. Calculate how much money is left over. Discuss saving vs. spending the remainder.
8. Compare different budget plans: 'Could you plan a different day that costs less but is still fun?'
materials_needed: Play money or printed money images

slides.heading: Family Budget Day
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our super fun math adventure today! It tells us we're going to learn about planning a "Family Budget Day," which means using math to figure out how to spend money wisely, just like grown-ups do. It's going to be real-world math, which is extra exciting!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a price list card with at least 12 activities/items at various price points. Create a budget worksheet with columns for Item, Cost Per Person, Number of People, and Total Cost. Have play money available for hands-on counting.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for our money adventure! We have play money – that's pretend cash to help us count, and we start with $100. There's a price list card that tells us how much everything costs, like movie tickets or yummy ice cream. We also have a budget worksheet, which is like a special paper to write down all our choices and costs, and a pencil to do the writing. A calculator is there too, just to double-check our math, like a helpful friend!

slides.text: Introduce the concept: 'Every family has to make decisions about money. When we plan how to spend our money before we spend it, that is called a BUDGET. Today you are the family budget planner!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding what a "budget" is. Think of it like planning a treasure hunt before you go – you need to know where you're going and what you need! A budget is just planning how you'll spend your money before you actually spend it, so you don't run out too fast. Today, *you* get to be the boss of the money and plan a super fun day for your pretend family!

slides.text: Present the challenge: 'Your family of 4 has exactly $100 for a fun day out. Here is a list of things you could do and how much each costs. You must plan a great day WITHOUT going over $100.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the big challenge! Imagine your family – that's 4 people total – has exactly $100 for a whole day of fun. You have a list of all sorts of cool things you can do, like visit a museum or get ice cream, and it tells you how much each one costs. Your job is to pick activities and make sure the total cost stays at or under $100. Can you plan the most amazing day without spending too much?

slides.text: Model the first calculation: 'If movie tickets cost $10 per person and there are 4 people, how much is that? $10 times 4 equals $40. Write that on your budget sheet. How much money is left from $100?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's learn how to figure out costs with an example! See, movie tickets cost $10 for one person, but there are 4 people in our family. So, we need to multiply $10 by 4 to find the total cost for everyone, which is $40. We'll write that down on our budget sheet! Now, think about it: if we started with $100 and spent $40, how much money do we have left to plan the rest of our awesome day?

slides.text: Let the child plan independently: 'Now choose the rest of your day. Remember to multiply each cost by 4 people and keep a running total. Check — are you still under $100?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where your planning skills really shine! Look at the price list and choose what else your family would love to do. Remember, for each thing you pick, you need to multiply its cost by 4 people to get the total for your family. Keep adding up the costs as you go, and keep your eye on that $100 limit – are you still under?

slides.prompt: Create two different budget plans for your family's day out. Plan A should be the most fun day possible within $100. Plan B should be a budget-friendly day that costs under $50. Calculate the total for each and find the difference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a super fun part: planning *two* different days out! First, create "Plan A," where you plan the absolute most fun day you can imagine, but you *must* stay within the $100 budget. Then, for "Plan B," think about how to have a great time but spend much less, maybe under $50! After you figure out the total cost for both plans, tell me how much less money Plan B costs than Plan A.

slides.text: Compare the two plans: 'Look at both budgets. The expensive plan and the budget plan can both be wonderful days! Managing money well means making thoughtful choices. You used addition, subtraction, and multiplication to plan real spending — that is powerful math!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a budget using multiplication and addition, stay within a spending limit, and compare costs of different plans?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at your two amazing plans! You can see that even a super fun, maybe more expensive day, and a more budget-friendly day can both be wonderful ways to spend time together. You used addition, subtraction, and multiplication to make smart choices with money, which is exactly what real families do! You're officially a budgeting whiz!

parent_notes: Financial literacy is one of the most practical applications of elementary math, and Montessori education emphasizes connecting learning to real life. This lesson uses every operation the child has learned — addition for totaling costs, subtraction for finding remaining budget, and multiplication for per-person pricing. The decision-making aspect adds a layer that pure computation does not: the child must weigh wants against constraints. This is executive function in action. You can extend this powerfully by involving the child in a real family budget decision — let them help plan an actual outing or grocery trip within a real budget. Children who learn budgeting early develop healthier relationships with money. The comparison between two budget plans introduces the concept of trade-offs, a fundamental economic idea.

title: The Modern World — Technology and the Information Age
description: Students explore how technology has transformed the modern world, from the first computers to the internet, smartphones, and digital communication. They trace the accelerating pace of invention and consider how technology connects people across the globe.
instructions:
1. 'We have traveled through all of human history this year. Now we arrive at YOUR time — the world you live in right now! What makes our time different from all the others?'
2. Present a mini-timeline of modern technology: first computers (1940s-50s, room-sized), personal computers (1980s), the World Wide Web (1991), smartphones (2007), tablets, social media, video calls.
3. Compare: 'Your great-grandparents could not imagine video calls. Your grandparents grew up without the internet. Your parents got their first smartphones as teenagers. You have grown up with all of this!'
4. Discuss how technology changed daily life: communication (letters to email to instant messaging), information (libraries to search engines), entertainment (radio to streaming), shopping (stores to online).
5. Introduce the concept of the Information Age — we live in a time when information travels instantly around the world.
6. Activity: Create a 'Then and Now' chart comparing how people did things 100 years ago vs. today.
7. 'Technology is a tool. Like all tools, it can be used wisely or unwisely. What do you think makes someone a wise user of technology?'
materials_needed: Pictures of early computers vs. modern devices

slides.heading: The Information Age
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like a big welcome mat for our new topic! It tells us we're going to talk about the "Information Age" and how "Technology" has changed our "Modern World," which is the world we live in right now. Isn't it exciting to learn about the time you're actually living in?

items: Pictures of early vs. modern computers
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare or print a visual timeline showing major technology milestones from 1940 to present. Gather images comparing old and new technology (rotary phone vs. smartphone, typewriter vs. laptop, etc.).
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, we need to gather our supplies for our activity! We've got a timeline that shows cool inventions, pictures of old and new gadgets, a special chart to fill out, colored pencils, and drawing paper. You'll want to grab these with a grown-up's help so we're all ready to go!

slides.text: Connect to the year's journey: 'All year we have traveled through time — from the Big Bang to ancient civilizations to world wars. Now we have arrived at TODAY. You are living in one of the most extraordinary periods in all of human history: the Information Age.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we've been traveling through all of history, from dinosaurs to knights? Well, guess what? We've finally arrived at TODAY, which is a super special time called the Information Age! It's like we've reached the most exciting part of the adventure, and it's all happening right now.

slides.text: Walk through the technology timeline: 'The first computers in the 1940s filled entire rooms! By the 1980s, computers fit on a desk. In 1991, the World Wide Web was invented — connecting computers around the world. In 2007, the first smartphone was released. Now billions of people carry powerful computers in their pockets.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this timeline! It shows how computers used to be as big as a whole room, but now we carry even smaller, more powerful ones in our pockets called smartphones. It's amazing how quickly things have changed, making it possible to connect with people all over the world in just seconds!

slides.text: Discuss the transformation: 'Think about how people used to communicate — they wrote letters that took days or weeks to arrive. Now we can video call someone on the other side of the planet instantly. How has technology changed the way we learn, play, shop, and talk to each other?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Think about how your parents or grandparents used to talk to friends far away. They probably wrote letters that took a long time to arrive! Now, we can see and talk to people across the whole planet right away using video calls. How do you think all this fast technology has changed how we learn, play, and even shop?

slides.text: Reflect on wise technology use: 'Technology is a powerful tool, just like fire was for early humans. It can be used to learn, create, and connect — or it can waste our time. What does it mean to use technology wisely?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is asking us to think like wise inventors! Technology is a super powerful tool, like a magic wand, that can help us do amazing things. But just like any tool, we have to be careful how we use it. What do you think it means to use technology in a smart and helpful way?

slides.prompt: Create a 'Then and Now' chart with at least 6 comparisons showing how technology changed daily life. Draw pictures for each comparison. Examples: letter vs. email, horse vs. car, candle vs. light bulb, library vs. search engine.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make our "Then and Now" chart! You'll pick at least six things, like how people used to write letters but now we use email, or how they rode horses but now we drive cars. Draw a picture for each one to show the difference between the past and our amazing modern world!

slides.text: Place this era on the grand timeline: 'YOU are living in the Information Age. The changes happening now are as significant as the invention of writing in Mesopotamia or the printing press in the Renaissance. You are part of history being made right now!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe major technology milestones, explain how technology has transformed daily life, and discuss responsible technology use?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've learned so much about how technology is changing everything, and you are living right in the middle of it all – the Information Age! It's like you're a part of history being made right now, just like people were when they invented writing a long, long time ago. You're living in a truly incredible time!

parent_notes: This lesson brings the year's historical journey full circle — the child has traveled from the beginning of time to their own moment in history. The Montessori concept of cosmic education is beautifully embodied here: the child sees themselves as part of the ongoing story of human civilization. The 'Then and Now' comparisons help children appreciate both the speed of change and the continuity of human needs (we still communicate, learn, travel, and create — just with different tools). The discussion about wise technology use is not meant to be preachy but reflective — help your child think critically about their own relationship with technology. This is preparation for the digital citizenship they will need as they grow. The key insight for children: every generation inherits the tools of the past and creates new ones for the future. What will THEY create?

title: Mapping Global Connections — Trade, Travel, and the Internet
description: Students explore how the modern world is interconnected through trade routes, air travel, and digital communication. They map global connections by tracing where everyday products come from and how information flows around the world.
instructions:
1. 'Today we are going to discover something amazing — how connected our world really is!'
2. Take 5 everyday objects (banana, shirt, toy, phone, book) and research where each was made or grown. Mark origins on a world map with colored pins or dots.
3. Draw lines from each origin to your home. 'Look at all these connections! Your breakfast, your clothes, your toys — they came from all over the world.'
4. Discuss trade: 'Countries trade with each other because each place is good at producing different things. Bananas grow in tropical countries. Electronics are assembled in Asia. Cotton might be grown in one country and made into a shirt in another.'
5. Map air travel routes — show how you can fly almost anywhere in the world within 24 hours. Compare this to historical travel times (months by sailing ship!).
6. Discuss the internet: 'Undersea cables and satellites connect every continent. When you watch a video or send a message, data might travel through cables under the ocean!'
7. Create a 'My Global Connections' map showing all the ways the child's daily life connects to other countries.
materials_needed: String or yarn for connecting lines
Blank world map for student work

slides.heading: Our Connected World
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us the big idea for our lesson today: how everything in our world is connected, even though it seems so big! We're going to be like detectives, figuring out how things get from one place to another.

slides.setup_instructions: Check labels on 5 household items beforehand to know their countries of origin. Prepare a large world map on a wall or table. Have string and pins ready for creating visual connections.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, to be super map explorers, we need a few things! We’ve got a big world map, some colorful pins or stickers to mark places, and string or yarn to draw lines. We also need some everyday things from our house that have labels telling us where they were made or grown, and a blank map with colored pencils. Let's go grab those things with a grown-up!

slides.text: Begin with wonder: 'Look at these ordinary things — a banana, a shirt, a toy, a phone, a book. They seem simple, but each one has traveled an incredible journey to reach us. Let us trace where they came from!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for our first mission! See these everyday things like a banana or a shirt? They look normal, but they’ve been on a long journey to get to you. We're going to become super sleuths and find out exactly where each one started its adventure.

slides.text: Check labels together: 'This shirt says Made in Bangladesh. Find Bangladesh on the map and place a pin there. Now draw a line from Bangladesh all the way to our home. That shirt traveled thousands of miles to get here!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let’s pick up your shirt. Look closely at the tag – it says it was made in Bangladesh! Can you find Bangladesh on our big world map? Great job! Now, take a piece of string and connect that spot on the map all the way back to where we live. Wow, that shirt traveled super far to get to you!

slides.text: Discuss global trade: 'Countries trade because each place is good at different things. Ecuador grows bananas. China assembles electronics. India produces cotton. When countries trade, everyone gets things they could not easily make themselves.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know how some countries have lots of tall mountains and others have sunny beaches? Well, different places are really good at making or growing different things! Some countries are perfect for growing yummy bananas, while others are amazing at building things like phones or making soft cotton for clothes. Trading means everyone can get stuff they can't make themselves.

slides.text: Expand to digital connections: 'The internet connects the whole world through cables under the ocean and satellites in space. When you watch a video, that data might travel through a cable on the ocean floor from another continent! The world has never been more connected.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine sending a message or watching a video – did you know that information can travel through super-long cables that are actually at the bottom of the ocean? And there are also satellites way up in space that help connect us all! It’s like the whole world has its own secret internet highway.

slides.prompt: Create your own 'My Global Connections' map. Trace where at least 8 items in your home come from. Draw lines connecting each origin to your home. Add internet and travel connections too. Color-code your lines: blue for trade, red for travel routes, green for digital connections.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the map creator! Pick at least eight things in your house and find out where they came from, just like we did with the shirt. Draw lines on your blank map to show their journeys, and use different colors for things that traveled by boat or truck, things you can fly to, and things that travel through the internet.

slides.text: Step back and look at the map: 'Look at all those lines! Your daily life connects you to dozens of countries. We are all part of one global community. Understanding these connections helps us be responsible citizens of the world.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace the origins of everyday products, map global trade connections, and explain how trade, travel, and the internet connect the world?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at your map! See all those colorful lines? It shows how your breakfast, your toys, and even the videos you watch connect you to people all over the world. We're all part of one big team, and understanding these connections helps us take care of our planet together.

parent_notes: This lesson makes the abstract concept of globalization concrete and personal. When a child discovers that their morning banana came from Ecuador, their shirt from Bangladesh, and their toy from China, geography becomes real and relevant. The mapping activity reinforces all the geographic knowledge from the year — the child must locate countries and continents to trace connections. The discussion of trade introduces basic economic concepts: specialization, comparative advantage, and interdependence. The internet discussion adds a modern layer — undersea cables are a fascinating topic for children who think the internet is invisible. This lesson naturally connects to the history lesson on the Information Age and sets up the environmental awareness discussion later this week. In Montessori terms, this is cosmic education at its finest: the child sees how all of humanity is interconnected.

title: Read-Aloud: Here We Are — Notes for Living on Planet Earth by Oliver Jeffers
description: This beautifully illustrated book introduces the concept of our shared planet — its lands, seas, people, and the importance of caring for each other and the Earth. It connects perfectly to the week's themes of global connection, technology, and environmental awareness.
instructions:
1. Show the cover: 'This book is written as a letter to a new baby, explaining everything about our planet. But it is really a letter to ALL of us.'
2. Read slowly, pausing to appreciate the illustrations.
3. When the book describes land and sea: 'We have studied all of this! You know the continents, the oceans, the landforms.'
4. When it describes the diversity of people: 'All these different people, in all these different places, are connected — just like we mapped today!'
5. When it talks about kindness and caring: 'This is maybe the most important lesson of all. We share this planet.'
6. After reading, discuss: 'If YOU were writing a letter to explain Earth to someone new, what would you say? What is the most important thing to know about living here?'
7. Have the child write or draw their own 'Note for Living on Planet Earth.'
materials_needed: Here We Are by Oliver Jeffers (or similar book about our planet)

slides.heading: Here We Are
slides.subheading: Notes for Living on Planet Earth

slides.mascot_explanation: Now we see the things we need for our activity! We have the book "Here We Are," some paper for us to write or draw on, and some colorful pencils. Make sure you have these ready so we can get started on our creative project!

slides.text: Introduce the book: 'Oliver Jeffers wrote this book as a letter to his newborn son, explaining what Earth is like. But as we read, I think you will see it is a letter to everyone — including us.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part tells us how to start our reading adventure. The person reading will introduce the book by explaining that the author wrote it like a letter to his baby, but it's really a message for all of us about our world.

When we see Earth from far away, we'll remember all the continents and oceans we've learned about, and when we see all the different people, we'll think about how we're all connected.

slides.text: At the end, discuss: 'The book says there is much to see and do. What have YOU seen and learned this year about our planet? What do you think is the most important thing about living on Earth?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important part after we finish reading! We'll think about everything we saw in the book and talk about what *you* think is the most important thing to know about living on Earth, based on what we've learned this year.

slides.prompt: Write and illustrate your own 'Notes for Living on Planet Earth.' Include at least 3 things you think are the most important for someone to know about our world. This can be about nature, people, kindness, or anything you think matters most.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the magic happens! You're going to create your very own "Notes for Living on Planet Earth" by writing and drawing. Think of at least three things that are super important for someone to know about our world, whether it's about nature, people, or being kind.

slides.text: Share responses: 'Your notes are beautiful. You know so much about this planet — its history, its geography, its people, and its science. Carrying that knowledge means you can help take care of it.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child articulate important ideas about Earth and humanity, connecting personal knowledge to themes of global community and stewardship?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the wonderful notes you've made! You've shown how much you know about our planet, from its amazing places to how we can all be kind to each other. Your ideas are so important, and they help us all remember how to take great care of our Earth.

parent_notes: Oliver Jeffers' Here We Are is a perfect companion to this week's themes of global connection and environmental awareness. The book's gentle, awe-filled tone mirrors the Montessori approach to cosmic education — presenting the world as wonderful, interconnected, and worthy of care. The child's response activity reveals their values and understanding. Some children will focus on nature, others on kindness, others on fun facts about the planet. All responses are valid and revealing. If you cannot find this specific book, any book that celebrates our shared planet works beautifully. The key is the discussion afterward — connecting the book's message to everything the child has learned this year about the world. This is a quiet, reflective counterpoint to the more active research and mapping activities this week.

title: Capstone Research — Gathering and Organizing Sources
description: Students continue their capstone research project by gathering information from multiple sources and organizing their notes into categories that match their subtopics. They practice the essential research skills of evaluating sources, taking notes, and organizing information.
instructions:
1. Review the project plan from Day 1: 'You chose [topic] and identified your subtopics. Today we dive deep into research!'
2. Discuss sources: 'A good researcher uses multiple sources — books, encyclopedias, maps, and sometimes reliable websites. Using more than one source helps us find accurate information.'
3. Model how to take notes: read a passage, close the book, write the key facts in your own words. 'We never copy sentences directly — we put it in our own words.'
4. Set up a sorting system: one section of the table or one folder pocket for each subtopic.
5. Child reads and takes notes, sorting each note card into the correct subtopic pile.
6. After research time, review the piles: 'Which subtopic has the most information? Which needs more? This tells us where to focus next.'
7. Begin creating an outline from the organized notes.

slides.heading: Research Deep Dive
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the title page of a super exciting adventure! It's called "Research Deep Dive," and it means we're going to become amazing information detectives today, looking for all sorts of cool facts to help us learn about your special project. We'll be gathering and organizing all the clues we find!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up research stations with reference materials. Prepare subtopic labels matching the child's project plan. Have an outline template ready for the end of the session.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool tools we need for our detective work! We have reference books, which are like treasure chests full of facts. Index cards are where we'll write down our clues, and the subtopic labels will help us sort them. Pencils are for writing, a project folder keeps everything safe, and an outline template is like a map for building your final report. Go grab all these things with a grown-up's help!

slides.text: Review the plan: 'Yesterday you chose your topic and identified your subtopics. Today you become a detective — hunting for the best information to make your report amazing.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember yesterday when you picked your awesome topic and decided what big questions you wanted to answer about it? Well, today is all about finding the answers! Think of yourself as a super sleuth, and we're going to hunt for the best information to make your project super interesting and complete.

slides.text: Teach source evaluation: 'Good researchers use more than one source. If you find the same fact in two different books, you can be more confident it is accurate. Always write down where you found each fact.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a really important part of being a smart researcher! It tells us that we shouldn't just trust the first thing we read. By looking in more than one book or source, we can be super sure that the facts we find are true, just like how you know something is real if two friends tell you the same thing. We'll also make sure to remember *where* we found each fact!

slides.text: Model note-taking: 'Watch me. I read this paragraph about [topic]. Now I close the book. What were the key facts? I write them in my OWN words on a card. I never copy word for word — that is someone else's words, not mine.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, watch closely! This is how we take notes like a pro. I'm going to read a little bit from this book, then I'll close it and think about the most important parts. Then, I'll write those important facts down on an index card, but I'll use my *own* words. We never want to copy exactly because it's like saying someone else's idea is yours!

slides.text: Organize by subtopic: 'As you take notes, sort each card into the correct pile. All facts about [subtopic 1] go here, [subtopic 2] there. This will make writing your report much easier!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this is where we get organized! Imagine you have different piles for different things you're learning about. As you write down each fact on a note card, you'll put it in the right pile based on your subtopics. This way, when you're ready to build your report, all the information about one part of your topic will be together, making it super easy!

slides.prompt: Research your capstone topic using at least 2 different sources. Take at least 15 note cards, each with one fact in your own words. Sort them by subtopic. Then begin creating an outline showing the order you will present your information.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, detective, it's your turn to shine! For the next 25 minutes, you're going to read from at least two different books and write down at least 15 cool facts on your note cards, using your own words. Remember to put each card in the right pile for your subtopics. Then, take a look at the outline template and start thinking about how you want to share all these amazing facts!

slides.text: Review progress: 'You have organized research like a professional! Look at your notes — all sorted and ready to become a report. Next time we will start turning these notes into paragraphs.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child gather information from multiple sources, paraphrase facts in their own words, and organize notes by subtopic?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Look at all these organized notes you gathered – you're like a research superstar! All those piles show you've found so much great information, and it's all ready to be turned into your amazing report. You successfully found facts from different places, wrote them in your own words, and sorted them like a pro!

parent_notes: Research skills are among the most valuable tools in education, and this lesson teaches them explicitly. The note-taking method — read, close, write in your own words — prevents plagiarism while building comprehension. Sorting notes by subtopic teaches organizational thinking that will serve the child through all levels of education. Resist the temptation to do the research for the child. If they struggle to find information, help them develop better search strategies rather than handing them answers. The outline is a bridge between research and writing — it transforms a pile of facts into a structured argument. If your child finds outlining frustrating, try having them physically arrange their note cards in order on the table first. The tactile, visual arrangement often clicks better than abstract outlining.

title: Personal Finance — Saving, Spending, and Giving
description: Students explore the three uses of money — saving, spending, and giving — through a hands-on simulation with three jars. They apply fraction and percentage concepts to divide money and practice making thoughtful financial decisions.
instructions:
1. 'Yesterday we learned about budgeting. Today we learn what wise people do with their money: they divide it into three categories.'
2. Introduce three jars (or envelopes): SAVE, SPEND, GIVE.
3. Explain each: Save is for big future goals, Spend is for things you need and enjoy now, Give is for helping others.
4. Present the scenario: 'You earned $30 doing chores and helping neighbors. How will you divide it?'
5. Explore different divisions: What if you put half in savings? That is $15. What is left? How could you split the remaining $15?
6. Practice with fractions: 1/3 of $30 = $10 each. 1/2 for saving, 1/4 for spending, 1/4 for giving.
7. Discuss goals: 'What are you saving FOR? A book? A trip? What cause would you give to?'
8. Child creates their own personal plan for dividing money.
9. Compare: 'If you saved $10 every month, how much would you have in 6 months? In a year?'
materials_needed: Three jars or envelopes labeled Save, Spend, Give
Fraction circles or strips for reference

slides.heading: Save, Spend, Give
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our money adventure! It shows us the three super important things we can do with money: Save, Spend, and Give. Knowing these three things helps us become really smart with our money, just like grown-ups do!

slides.setup_instructions: Label three jars or envelopes clearly: SAVE, SPEND, GIVE. Prepare play money in small denominations for easy dividing. Have fraction materials available for visual support.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is our "Money Lab" setup! We've got three jars, one for Saving, one for Spending, and one for Giving – make sure they're labeled nice and clear. We also have pretend money, paper and pencils for writing, and some cool fraction pieces to help us see how we're splitting our money. Go grab all these things so we can get started!

slides.text: Introduce the concept: 'There are really only three things you can do with money: save it for later, spend it now, or give it to help others. Wise money managers do ALL THREE.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding what we *can* do with money. Think about it: you can put some away for something special later (that's saving!), use some for a toy or a snack right now (that's spending!), or share some with someone who needs it (that's giving!). Wise people do all three!

slides.text: Present the three jars: 'SAVE is for big goals — things you cannot buy today but are working toward. SPEND is for things you need or enjoy right now. GIVE is for helping others — people, animals, or causes you care about.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's get to know our jars! The 'SAVE' jar is for those big dreams, like a new bike or a cool video game you want later. The 'SPEND' jar is for things you need or want *today*, like maybe a yummy treat. And the 'GIVE' jar is super special because it's for helping others, like donating to an animal shelter or a friend who needs a little help.

slides.text: Practice dividing: 'You earned $30. If you put 1/3 into each jar, how much goes in each? $30 divided by 3 equals $10 each. But you get to choose YOUR ratio! Maybe you want to save more — half in savings. What is half of $30?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the math fun begins! Imagine you have $30. If you wanted to put an equal amount into each of the three jars, you'd put $10 in each, because $30 divided into 3 parts is $10. But guess what? You get to decide how much goes where! What if you wanted to save *half* of your money? How much would that be?

slides.text: Calculate growth over time: 'If you save $10 each month, after 1 month you have $10. After 2 months? After 6 months? After a whole year? $10 times 12 equals $120! Saving small amounts adds up to big amounts.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! If you decide to save just $10 every single month, imagine how much you'll have after a whole year! That's like saving $10 for every month, and there are 12 months in a year. So, $10 multiplied by 12 is $120 – see how saving even a little bit adds up to a lot over time?

slides.prompt: Create your personal money plan. Decide what fraction of each dollar you would put in Save, Spend, and Give. Write your savings goal and calculate how long it would take to reach it. Then practice dividing $30, $60, and $100 using your chosen ratios.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the money boss! Take your paper and pencil and decide how *you* want to divide your money. Maybe you want to save most of it for a big goal, or maybe you want to spend a little now and give some away. Write down your plan and figure out how long it would take to save up for something special!

slides.text: Reflect: 'You now know the secret that many adults wish they had learned as children — divide your money wisely, save for the future, enjoy the present, and always share with others. You used fractions, multiplication, and addition to make a real financial plan!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child divide money using fractions, calculate savings over time using multiplication, and articulate a personal financial plan?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You just created your very own money plan, figuring out how to save for the future, enjoy today, and help others. You learned how to use fractions and even multiplication to make smart choices with your money. That's a secret that helps people your whole life!

parent_notes: The Save-Spend-Give framework is one of the most powerful financial literacy tools for children. It teaches that money is not just for buying things — it is a tool for achieving goals and helping others. The math involved is substantial: fractions (dividing into portions), multiplication (projecting savings over time), and addition (running totals). Consider making this real by helping your child set up actual jars at home. Even small amounts — birthday money, coins found in the couch — become meaningful when the child is making conscious decisions about allocation. The 'Give' jar is especially important in Montessori philosophy, which emphasizes community responsibility and grace and courtesy. Let the child choose their own giving cause — it develops empathy and agency. Studies show that children who learn these habits early maintain them into adulthood.

title: Environmental Science — Conservation and Our Carbon Footprint
description: Students learn about environmental conservation by exploring what a carbon footprint is, how everyday actions affect the planet, and what individuals and communities can do to reduce their impact. They conduct a personal carbon footprint assessment.
instructions:
1. 'All year we studied the natural world — organisms, ecosystems, earth science, physics, and chemistry. Today we ask an important question: How do humans affect all of these systems?'
2. Introduce the concept of a carbon footprint — the amount of greenhouse gases our activities produce.
3. Explain simply: burning fossil fuels (gas, coal, oil) for energy produces carbon dioxide, which traps heat in the atmosphere.
4. Walk through a typical day and identify carbon-producing activities: driving a car, using electricity, eating food that was shipped from far away, throwing things in the garbage instead of recycling.
5. Create a simple carbon footprint assessment: rate each category (transportation, energy, food, waste) as high, medium, or low for your family.
6. Discuss conservation strategies: walking/biking, turning off lights, eating local foods, reducing waste, recycling and composting.
7. 'Small actions by millions of people create big change. What can WE do?'
8. Begin drafting a personal/family action plan.
materials_needed: Paper and colored pencils for action plan

slides.heading: Our Carbon Footprint
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of a book, telling us what we're going to learn about today: "Our Carbon Footprint" and how we can help the environment! It's like we're going to become super detectives for our planet.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a simple carbon footprint assessment worksheet with categories: transportation, energy at home, food choices, and waste. Create or print a basic diagram showing the greenhouse effect.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now we need to get our detective tools ready! We’ve got a worksheet to help us figure out our carbon footprint, a picture that shows how heat gets trapped around the Earth, some colorful pictures of ways to help the planet, and paper and pencils to draw, plus a calculator. You'll need to ask a grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: Connect to the year: 'This year we studied ecosystems, food webs, energy, and how Earth works. All those systems are connected — and humans are part of them. Today we explore how our daily choices affect the planet.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember all the cool stuff we learned this year about nature, like how plants grow and how animals live together? Well, all of that is connected, and what we do every single day can affect it all. Today, we're going to see how our everyday choices are like tiny footprints we leave on our planet.

slides.text: Explain carbon footprint: 'When we burn fossil fuels — gasoline in cars, coal for electricity — we release carbon dioxide gas. This gas acts like a blanket around Earth, trapping heat. A carbon footprint measures how much of this gas our activities create.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, what's a "carbon footprint"? Imagine when we drive a car or use electricity, we're burning things like gas and coal, which makes a gas called carbon dioxide. This gas acts like a cozy blanket around the Earth, but if it gets too thick, it traps too much heat, which isn't good for our planet. Our carbon footprint is just a way to measure how much of that heat-trapping gas our actions make.

slides.text: Walk through a day: 'Let us trace one day. You wake up — the alarm uses electricity. You eat breakfast — where did that food come from? You drive to an activity — the car burns gasoline. Each of these creates a small amount of carbon dioxide. It adds up!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let’s think about a normal day. When your alarm clock buzzes, that uses electricity! When you eat breakfast, where did that food come from? If you ride in a car, the engine uses gas. All these things make that carbon dioxide gas, and even though each one is small, they all add up over the day, kind of like adding up little pebbles to make a big pile!

slides.text: Explore solutions: 'The wonderful news is that we can REDUCE our footprint! Walking instead of driving. Turning off lights. Eating foods grown nearby. Recycling and composting instead of throwing things away. Every small action matters.'
slides.mascot_explanation: The super exciting news is that we can actually make our footprints smaller! We can choose to walk or ride our bikes sometimes instead of driving, and remember to turn off lights when we leave a room. Eating yummy food that's grown close by and recycling or composting instead of just throwing things in the trash are also fantastic ways to help.

slides.prompt: Complete your family's carbon footprint assessment. Rate each category (transportation, energy, food, waste) as high, medium, or low. Then create a 'Family Action Plan' poster with at least 5 specific things your family can do to reduce your carbon footprint.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a planet helper! Take your worksheet and think about your family's driving, how much electricity you use, the food you eat, and how much trash you make, and decide if each one is high, medium, or low. Then, grab your paper and colored pencils and make a cool poster showing at least five things your family can do to help shrink your carbon footprint!

slides.text: Celebrate the plan: 'You are now an environmental scientist AND an activist! Understanding the problem is the first step. Creating a plan is the second. Taking action — that is what changes the world. You are ready to be part of the solution.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what a carbon footprint is, identify sources of greenhouse gases in daily life, and propose specific conservation actions?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You figured out your family's carbon footprint and even made a plan to help our planet. That’s amazing! Remember how we learned that little actions can make a big difference? You are now officially an environmental scientist and a real-life planet protector!

parent_notes: Environmental science is where all the year's science learning converges — ecology, earth science, chemistry, and physics all play a role in understanding climate and conservation. Present this topic with hope and agency, not fear. Children who feel empowered to act respond much better than children who feel overwhelmed by doom. The carbon footprint assessment makes the abstract personal: your family's specific choices have specific impacts. The action plan gives the child ownership — let them choose which changes they care most about. Follow through on at least one item from the plan (even something simple like starting a recycling station) to show that learning leads to action. This connects beautifully to Montessori's cosmic education: the child understands their place in the web of life and their responsibility to care for it. Maria Montessori herself wrote extensively about children as stewards of the Earth.

title: Art of the Future — Designing Solutions Through Art
description: Students combine artistic expression with environmental awareness by designing inventions or solutions for environmental challenges. They create detailed drawings or models of imaginary green technology, connecting science concepts to creative thinking.
instructions:
1. 'Artists and scientists are not so different — they both imagine things that do not yet exist and work to make them real! Today you are both.'
2. Discuss real green inventions: solar panels, electric cars, wind turbines, water filtration systems.
3. Show how these started as ideas and drawings before becoming real.
4. Challenge: 'Design YOUR invention that helps the planet. It can be realistic or fantastical — a machine that cleans the ocean, a building that makes its own energy, a vehicle that runs on something unusual.'
5. Planning phase: What problem does your invention solve? How does it work? What does it look like?
6. Drawing/building phase: Create a detailed illustration or 3D model with labels explaining each part.
7. Write an inventor's description explaining the invention and how it helps the environment.
8. Present to the family like a pitch to investors!
materials_needed: Pictures of real green technology for inspiration

slides.heading: Green Inventions
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page for our super exciting project! It tells us we're going to be "Green Inventions" designers, which means we'll use our amazing art skills to invent things that help our planet. Think of it as being an artist and a scientist all rolled into one!

slides.setup_instructions: Display pictures of real green technology for inspiration. Set up an art station with plenty of materials. Have recycled materials available (boxes, tubes, bottle caps) for optional 3D model building.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our inventing adventure! We have big paper for drawing, colorful pencils, markers, and crayons to make our ideas pop, and even some recycled things like boxes and tubes if you want to build a 3D model. We also have special "inventor's templates" to help us write about our amazing creations. Make sure you have a grown-up help you gather all these supplies!

slides.text: Connect art and science: 'Every great invention started as an idea in someone's imagination, then became a drawing, then became real. Solar panels, wind turbines, electric cars — someone IMAGINED them first. Today YOU are the inventor.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about how amazing inventors and artists are so similar! Just like how someone imagined a car that doesn't use gas or panels that catch sunshine, you're going to use your imagination today to dream up something new. So, get ready to be a super-smart inventor, because your awesome ideas are where the magic starts!

slides.text: Brainstorm problems to solve: 'What environmental problems did we learn about? Ocean pollution? Air pollution? Endangered animals? Too much garbage? Pick a problem that matters to YOU.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to think like a detective and find a problem our planet needs help with! We've talked about things like trash in the ocean or dirty air, and maybe you can think of others. Just pick one problem that makes you go "Hmm, I want to fix that!" because your invention will be its superhero.

slides.text: Plan the invention: 'What does your invention do? How does it work? Draw it large with many details. Label every part. Inventors always label their designs so others can understand them.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where your invention really starts to take shape on paper! Think about what your amazing machine or creation will do, and then draw it super big and with lots of details. It's like a treasure map for your invention, so make sure you label all the important parts so everyone knows what they are.

slides.text: Write the description: 'Every invention needs a description. What is it called? What problem does it solve? How does it work? Why is it important? Write this below your drawing or on a separate page.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Every fantastic invention needs a story, and that's what this step is for! You'll write down what your invention is called, what big problem it's going to solve, and how it works its magic. Explaining it clearly helps everyone understand why your idea is so super important for our Earth.

slides.prompt: Design and illustrate your green invention. Include a title, detailed labeled drawing, and a written description of at least 5 sentences explaining what it does and how it helps the planet. Optionally, build a 3D model from recycled materials!
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, inventor, this is your big chance to shine! You're going to create a colorful drawing of your invention, label all its cool parts, and write a description explaining how it helps our planet. If you're feeling extra creative, you can even build a 3D version using those recycled materials we gathered. You've got this!

slides.text: Present your invention: 'You are an inventor, an artist, and a scientist all at once! The world needs creative thinkers who care about the planet. Maybe one day YOUR real invention will help solve these problems.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify an environmental problem, design a creative solution, create a detailed labeled illustration, and explain their invention clearly?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at everything you've created! You imagined a problem, designed a super solution, and made it look amazing with your art. Presenting your invention shows everyone how smart and caring you are, and who knows, maybe your amazing idea will help make the real world a better place one day!

parent_notes: This lesson bridges art, science, and social responsibility beautifully. Design thinking — identifying a problem, brainstorming solutions, prototyping, and presenting — is a 21st-century skill used by engineers, entrepreneurs, and artists alike. The child's invention does not need to be realistic; the thinking process matters more than the feasibility. A child who designs a 'rainbow machine that turns pollution into flowers' is exercising the same creative muscles as an engineer designing a real air filter. Celebrate imagination over realism. The presentation component adds language skills (explaining, persuading) to the art and science. If your child wants to build a 3D model, this becomes a powerful hands-on engineering activity. Save these inventions — they make wonderful additions to the portfolio and the week 35 presentations.

title: Household Sustainability Audit
description: Students conduct a real sustainability audit of their home, examining energy use, water consumption, waste production, and food sourcing. They apply observation, measurement, and data-recording skills to a meaningful real-world investigation.
instructions:
1. 'Scientists study the environment, but we do not have to go far — we can start right here in our own home! Today you are an environmental auditor.'
2. Create an audit checklist with categories: Energy (lights left on, appliance use, thermostat), Water (dripping faucets, shower length, garden watering), Waste (recycling, composting, single-use items), Food (local vs. shipped, packaging, food waste).
3. Walk through each room of the house together, making observations and notes.
4. For each category, rate your household: excellent, good, or needs improvement.
5. Count specific things: How many lights are on right now? How many items in the recycling vs. trash?
6. Calculate: If a dripping faucet wastes 1 gallon per day, how many gallons in a week? A month? A year?
7. Create a report card for your household with specific recommendations.
8. 'This is real science — observing, measuring, analyzing, and recommending changes!'
materials_needed: Tally counter or tally marks paper

slides.heading: Home Sustainability Audit
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a special mission notebook! It's telling us we're going to become "environmental auditors" and figure out how "green" our home is, which means how good we are at taking care of the planet right from our house. Isn't it exciting to be like a detective for the Earth?

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a sustainability audit checklist with categories for Energy, Water, Waste, and Food. Create a simple report card template with space for ratings and recommendations in each category.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now we need to get our detective tools ready! We've got our audit checklist to write things down, a clipboard and pencil to make it official, tally paper for counting, a calculator for some fun math, a report card template to give our house a grade, and some measuring cups just in case. You'll need to ask a grown-up to help you gather all these important supplies.

slides.text: Introduce the audit: 'An audit is when someone carefully examines something to see how it is doing. Companies get audited. Schools get audited. Today YOU are auditing our home to see how environmentally friendly it is!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like getting our instructions from the mission commander! It explains that an "audit" is just a fancy word for looking really closely at something to see how it's working. Today, *you* are the auditor, and you'll be examining our home to see how well we're helping the environment. You're going to be a real eco-detective!

slides.text: Start with energy: 'Walk through each room. Count how many lights are on. Check if appliances are plugged in when not in use. Look at the thermostat. Record everything on your checklist.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's start our investigation with energy! We're going to tiptoe through each room and be super observers: counting all the lights that are on, checking if any electronics are plugged in when we're not using them, and even looking at the thermostat to see how warm or cool we're keeping our house. You’ll write down all these energy secrets on your checklist.

slides.text: Move to water and waste: 'Check all faucets for drips. Look at the garbage and recycling — which has more? Count single-use plastic items in the kitchen. Record your findings.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next up are water and waste, two super important things for our planet! We'll carefully check every faucet to see if even a tiny drop is dripping out, and we'll peek into the trash and recycling bins to see what we're throwing away. You'll also look for those single-use plastics in the kitchen, like straws or plastic bags, and jot down all your findings.

slides.text: Calculate impact: 'If we leave 3 lights on for 5 extra hours a day, and each light uses a small amount of electricity, it adds up! If a dripping faucet wastes 1 gallon per day, that is 365 gallons per year!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is where we become super scientists and do some cool calculations! Imagine if a faucet drips just a little bit every single day – that adds up to a LOT of water wasted over a whole year, like filling up a bathtub many times! We’ll use our calculator to see how much energy or water we could save by making small changes.

slides.prompt: Complete your full household sustainability audit. Rate each category. Write a 'report card' with specific grades and at least 3 recommendations for improvement. Include one calculation showing the impact of a change (like how much water you could save by fixing a drip).
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the big activity where you get to be the boss! You'll finish checking everything in your house for energy, water, waste, and food, and then give each part a grade, like "excellent" or "needs improvement." Then, you'll write a special report card for our home and come up with at least three ideas to help us be even greener, maybe including one of those cool calculations you did!

slides.text: Present the report card: 'You just did real environmental science IN your own home! Your observations and calculations show where we are doing well and where we can improve. Let us pick one recommendation to start this week.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child systematically observe and record environmental data, perform relevant calculations, and make evidence-based recommendations?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You've just completed a real environmental audit of your home, just like a scientist! You observed, you counted, you calculated, and now you have a report card showing how our home is doing and how we can be even better helpers for the Earth. Let's pick one of your awesome ideas to try out this week!

parent_notes: This practical life lesson is Montessori at its most authentic — the child applies scientific observation, mathematical calculation, and ethical reasoning to their own real environment. The audit format teaches systematic thinking: examining one category at a time, collecting data, making judgments based on evidence, and proposing solutions. Take this activity seriously even when findings are inconvenient — if the child discovers you leave lights on or do not recycle something recyclable, model graceful acceptance of feedback! Implementing at least one of the child's recommendations shows that their work has real impact. The calculations (drip water waste over a year, energy from unnecessary lights) make math meaningful. This activity naturally extends all week and throughout summer. Many families find that a child-led sustainability effort creates lasting household changes.

title: Capstone Writing — Drafting the Research Report
description: Students begin writing the first draft of their capstone research report, transforming organized notes and outlines into connected paragraphs. They apply all the writing skills developed throughout the year: topic sentences, supporting details, transitions, and conclusions.
instructions:
1. Review the outline from the previous session: 'You have your research organized beautifully. Now comes the exciting part — writing your report!'
2. Review the structure of an expository paragraph: topic sentence, supporting details, concluding sentence.
3. Model writing the first paragraph together, using note cards as source material.
4. Discuss introductions: 'Your first paragraph should grab the reader's attention. Why is this topic fascinating? Start with a surprising fact or an interesting question.'
5. Child writes independently, working through subtopics one at a time.
6. Remind: 'This is a first draft. Focus on getting your ideas down. We will edit and polish later.'
7. After writing, read the draft aloud. 'Does it flow? Does each paragraph connect to the next?'
8. Mark places where illustrations will go — the report will be illustrated in the next session.
materials_needed: Organized note cards from previous session

slides.heading: Writing My Report
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing you the title of what we're doing today: "Writing My Report," and it reminds us that we're going to turn all our organized notes into a real report with paragraphs. It's like building a story with all the cool facts you've learned!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the child's note cards and outline from previous sessions easily accessible. Prepare a reference card showing paragraph structure (topic sentence, details, conclusion) and a list of transition words (First, Next, Additionally, Furthermore, In conclusion).
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our writing tools ready! We have our organized note cards and outline, which are like our treasure maps for writing. We also need lined paper and pencils to write on, a special card that shows how to build a good paragraph, and a list of transition words to help our writing flow smoothly.

slides.text: Set up for success: 'Today you transform from researcher to author! Your notes and outline are your road map — now you fill in the details with beautiful writing.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about getting ready to be an author! You've done a super job gathering all your research, and now it's time to use that information like a map to guide you as you write your amazing report. Think of yourself as a storyteller sharing important facts!

slides.text: Review paragraph structure: 'Every paragraph starts with a topic sentence that tells the reader what the paragraph is about. Then come 3 to 5 supporting details — the facts from your note cards. Finally, a sentence that wraps up the idea.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important reminder about how to build a strong paragraph. Each one needs a topic sentence to say what it's about, then some details from your notes to explain it, and a concluding sentence to wrap it all up nicely, just like putting a lid on a box.

slides.text: Model the introduction together: 'The first paragraph is special — it must make the reader want to keep going! Start with something fascinating: a surprising fact, a question, or a vivid description. Then tell the reader what your report is about.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to work on making our first paragraph really exciting! This is the introduction, and it needs to grab your reader's attention right away, maybe with a super surprising fact or a curious question, before telling them what your whole report will be about.

slides.text: Write freely: 'Now write your report, following your outline. Use your note cards for facts. Use transition words to connect ideas: First, Next, Additionally, Furthermore, Finally. Remember — this is a draft. Getting ideas down matters more than perfection.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the author! Follow your outline and use your note cards for all the facts, and don't forget to use those transition words to connect your ideas smoothly. Remember, this is just a first draft, so the most important thing is to get all your wonderful ideas down on paper.

slides.prompt: Write the first draft of your capstone research report. Include an introduction that hooks the reader, at least 3 body paragraphs (one for each subtopic), and mark where illustrations will go. Use transition words between paragraphs. Aim for at least one full page of writing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Your job now is to write the whole first draft of your report. Make sure you have that exciting introduction, at least three paragraphs with all your research details, and remember to put little marks where you think pictures would look great. Try to make it at least a page long!

slides.text: Read the draft aloud: 'Listen to how it sounds! You wrote a real research report — with an introduction, organized paragraphs, and facts from multiple sources. We will edit, illustrate, and finalize it next time. You should be incredibly proud!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a multi-paragraph expository text with an engaging introduction, organized body paragraphs with topic sentences and supporting details, and appropriate transitions?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You wrote a whole research report! Reading it aloud helps us hear how all your paragraphs connect and tell a complete story. Next time, we'll make it even better with illustrations and some polishing, but today you should feel super proud of being a published author!

parent_notes: This is where the year's writing instruction comes together. The child is synthesizing research skills (note-taking, organizing), writing skills (paragraph structure, transitions, introductions), and content knowledge (their chosen historical topic) into a single coherent piece. The first draft will not be perfect, and that is exactly right. Resist the urge to correct every error — the editing phase comes next. Focus on praising the content, the organization, and the effort. If the child gets stuck, have them talk through what they want to say, then write what they said. Many young writers can articulate ideas verbally before they can write them. Reading the draft aloud is a powerful self-editing technique — the ear catches awkwardness that the eye misses. Mark illustration spots now so the writing and art can complement each other in the final version.

title: Personal Finance — Smart Shopping and Comparison
description: Students apply math skills to real-world shopping decisions, comparing prices, calculating unit costs, understanding sales and discounts, and making informed purchasing decisions. They learn that math is the key to being a wise consumer.
instructions:
1. 'Wise shoppers use math every single time they go to the store! Today you learn the math of smart shopping.'
2. Present comparison shopping scenarios: Brand A cereal costs $4 for 12 ounces. Brand B costs $5 for 20 ounces. Which is a better deal?
3. Teach unit price: divide total price by quantity. $4 divided by 12 = about 33 cents per ounce. $5 divided by 20 = 25 cents per ounce. Brand B is cheaper per ounce!
4. Introduce discounts: '25% off means you pay 75% of the price. If something costs $20 and is 25% off, you save $5 and pay $15.'
5. Practice with sale flyers or created scenarios: calculate savings, compare brands, decide which deals are truly good.
6. Discuss marketing tricks: 'Just because something says SALE does not mean it is a good deal. You have to do the math!'
7. Create a mock shopping list with a $50 budget, comparing options and making the best choices.
materials_needed: Grocery flyers or created price comparison cards

slides.heading: Smart Shopping Math
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure! It tells us we're going to learn how to be super smart shoppers using math, and we'll be looking at how to compare prices and figure out discounts. It’s like learning the secret code to getting the best deals!

slides.setup_instructions: Create or gather price comparison scenarios. Prepare at least 6 comparison pairs with different sizes and prices. Have a simple discount chart showing common percentages (10%, 25%, 50%) and their decimal equivalents.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our tools ready for this shopping mission! We've got grocery flyers or price cards to look at, a calculator to help us with the numbers, a shopping list paper, pencils for writing, and pretend money to play with. Make sure you have all these things handy so we can start comparing prices like real pros!

slides.text: Introduce the concept: 'Every time someone goes to the store, they make math decisions. Is the big box a better deal? Is the sale price really a bargain? Today you learn the math that makes you a smart shopper.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is all about how math is like a superpower for shopping! Think about it: when you go to the store, you're always making choices, right? This slide reminds us that using math helps us make the *best* choices, so we don't waste our money and can get the most for it, just like a super spy using their gadgets!

slides.text: Teach unit pricing: 'To compare different sizes, find the price per unit. If 12 pencils cost $3, each pencil costs 25 cents. If 20 pencils cost $4, each costs 20 cents. The bigger pack is a better deal per pencil!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, imagine you're buying pencils. One pack has 12 pencils and costs $3, and another has 20 pencils and costs $4. How do we know which is the better deal? We figure out the "unit price" – that's the price for just *one* pencil! By dividing the total price by how many pencils there are, we can see that the bigger pack is actually cheaper for each pencil, even though it costs more overall.

slides.text: Introduce discounts: 'A 50% discount means half off — divide by 2. A 25% discount means one quarter off — divide by 4. A 10% discount is easy — just move the decimal point one place left. A $30 item at 10% off saves $3.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's talk about sales! When something says "25% off," it means you don't pay that whole price. We can figure out exactly how much money we save! For example, if something costs $30 and is 10% off, that means we save $3, which is pretty neat!

slides.text: Apply critical thinking: 'But wait — a good deal is not always worth buying! If you save $2 on something you do not need, you did not save $2 — you SPENT money you did not need to spend. Wise shopping means buying what you truly need at the best price.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is super important because it teaches us to think like detectives! Just because something has a big "SALE" sign doesn't always mean it's the best deal. We have to do the math ourselves to be sure. Remember, buying something you don't really need, even if it's on sale, still means you're spending money!

slides.prompt: Complete these challenges: (1) Compare 5 pairs of products and determine which is the better deal using unit pricing. (2) Calculate the sale price for 5 items with different discounts. (3) Create a shopping list that fits within a $50 budget, choosing the best deals for each item.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here comes the fun part where you get to be the shopper! You'll look at different products and figure out which one is the best deal using what we learned about unit prices. Then, you'll calculate how much things cost when they're on sale, and finally, you'll make your own shopping list trying to buy everything you need while staying under $50. You've got this!

slides.text: Celebrate: 'You are now a mathematical shopper! You can compare unit prices, calculate discounts, and make smart decisions with a budget. Next time you go to the store with your family, see if you can spot the best deals!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child calculate unit prices, compute discounts using percentages and fractions, and make budget-conscious shopping decisions?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You're officially a math whiz shopper! You learned how to compare prices like a pro, figure out discounts super fast, and even stick to a budget. Next time you're at the store, you can be the one spotting the coolest deals for your family!
